text:
So basically R's best feature, like python, (like everyone else has said) is it's decently curated ecosystem. R has packages for doing things that Julia is years behind on, even simple things like ANOVA's(please don't point me to the 5 abandoned anova packages in Julia).

Think of R as it's own thing. Don't use loops unless you're using Rcpp. Don't expect performance for anything other than I/O or packages that call out to other languages. Vectorize all of your code (gapply,lapply,apply,etc). If you can get past that... it's a pretty great scripting language for mathy stuff.

One cool feature of R is instead of having to print dumps of variables RStudio let's you just inspect them via the GUI. So if you have a nest of things going wrong you can just poke at them and piece it together but keep your console clean.

text: If a new statistical method has just been dropped, more than likely the code is in R, and its available in CRAN. So if you don't have time to write your own version - it's a serious life saver. Especially if there's a high chance it won't work for your problem statement, but you want to roll the dice anyways.
